0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-rubio-idUSKCN11600O	Florida Republicans pick Marco Rubio for Senate race: AP	"
WASHINGTON Marco Rubio
column2: who dropped out of the Republican presidential race earlier this year
column3: was chosen on Tuesday as the Republican Party nominee for a second U.S. Senate term from Florida
column4: according to the Associated Press.Rubio was projected to win the party nominating contest in Florida over novice politician Carlos Beruff
column5: a wealthy homebuilder. Rubio could face Democratic U.S. Representative Patrick Murphy
column6: who was expected to win his party's nominating contest
column7: in the Nov. 8 election.

column1: (Reporting by Richard Cowan; Editing by Peter Cooney)"
1	http://reuters.com/article/us-g20-china-trade-idUSKCN1152TO	Pacific trade pact remains top issue for Obama administration	"
WASHINGTON The successful conclusion of the Trans Pacific Partnership trade talks remains the top legislative item for the United States
column2: a top economic adviser to President Barack Obama said on Tuesday.White House National Security Council adviser Christina Segal-Knowles told a news conference ahead of the Sept. 4-5 G20 summit in China that talks on a trade pact with Europe were still in progress
column3: despite comments from France and Germany that they were in doubt.The Asian talks are stalled in Congress and both Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump have said they would not approve the deal in its current form
column4: if elected president in November.

column1: Segal-Knowles said corporate tax issues would be on the G20's agenda in China
column2: although when asked whether the European Union's tax ruling on Apple Inc's deal with Ireland would be discussed
column3: she did not directly address the issue facing the company.

column1: (Reporting by David Chance; Editing by Peter Cooney)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-cybersecurity-russia-idUSKCN1151TQ	Democrats seek FBI probe of allegations Russia seeking to influence U.S. vote	"
By Dustin Volz
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Democrats in Congress
column2: including party Senate leader Harry Reid
column3: asked the FBI to investigate concerns that the Russian government may be attempting to undermine the U.S. presidential election through cyber attacks that could include tampering with voting results.""The prospect of a hostile government actively seeking to undermine our free and fair elections represents one of the gravest threats to our democracy since the Cold War
column4: Reid said in a letter to FBI Director James Comey.Reid's letter
column5: dated Saturday
column6: was first obtained by The New York Times and shared on its website on Monday.It was followed on Tuesday by a letter from four Democrats asking Comey to assess whether campaign officials working for Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump may be colluding with Russian interests to carry out recent hacks against the Democratic National Committee and Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in order to ""interfere with the U.S. presidential election.""

column1: That letter was signed by Representatives Elijah Cummings
column2: John Conyers
column3: Elliot Engel and Bennie Thompson
column4: each of whom serves as the top Democrat on a different congressional committee. Republicans control both the House of Representatives and the Senate.Comey
column5: speaking at a cyber security conference on Tuesday
column6: declined to give details about what the Federal Bureau of Investigation was probing in connection with the political hacking but indicated the agency was closely watching what foreign countries are doing.""We take very seriously any effort by any actor
column7: ... especially nation states
column8: that moves beyond the collection of information ... and offers the prospect of an effort to influence the conduct of affairs in our country
column9: whether that is an election or something else

column1: The two letters follow a spate of hacking attacks targeting U.S. political databases
column2: including some that officials and cyber security experts have blamed on hackers working for the Russian government. Kremlin officials have denied that.The FBI examined breaches in voter registration databases in Illinois and Arizona but did not specify who might have been behind it.

column1: Reid said that the threat of Russian government tampering in the election was ""more extensive than widely known and may include the intent to falsify official election results.""He also voiced concerns about possible Russian government efforts to manipulate Trump's campaign ahead of the Nov. 8 election
column2: and to use it as a vehicle to advance the interests of Russian President Vladimir Putin. (Reporting by Dustin Volz and David Alexander; Editing by Frances Kerry and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-virginia-politics-idUSKCN1152OO	Poll shows Virginia lawmaker jailed in sex scandal leading mayor's race	"
A former Virginia politician who was jailed over a sex scandal involving a teenage girl leads a crowded field running for mayor of the state's capital city
column2: a poll showed on Tuesday. Joe Morrissey
column4: holds a commanding lead in the Richmond mayor's race with 28 percent of the vote city-wide
column5: according to the Christopher Newport University poll. The poll showed him about 12 points ahead of the nearest of his seven competitors.Morrissey pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of contributing to the delinquency of a minor in December 2014 for his relationship with a receptionist who began working in his office when she was 17. He is now married to the woman and they have two children.Morrissey
column6: who was first elected to the Virginia House of Delegates in 2007
column7: was sentenced to six months in jail and resigned from office. He switched from Democrat to run as an independent in the special election to fill his seat.

column1: During a three-month stay in an area jail
column2: Morrissey commuted to the state legislature on work release and also ran his re-election campaign.Morrissey stunned political pundits when he won in January 2015 while serving his jail sentence. He gave up his most recent bid to serve in the state Senate last September
column3: citing health problems.

column1: The poll was based on 600 live interviews with registered voters Aug. 18 through- 24 and has a margin of error of 4.9 percentage points.
Morrissey also had his license to practice law revoked by the Virginia State Bar Disciplinary Board in 2003.  (Reporting by Curtis Skinner in San Francisco; Editing by Dan Grebler)"
4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-garland-idUSKCN1152OK	Senator Grassley could be persuaded to hold hearing on Garland	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON U.S. Senator Chuck Grassley opened the door to holding a hearing on President Obama's Supreme Court nominee Merrick Garland if a majority of senators wish to do so after the Nov. 8 election
column2: in comments posted online Tuesday.Grassley
column3: an Iowa Republican
column4: vowed months ago that the Senate Judiciary Committee he chairs would not act this year to consider Garland's nomination
column5: saying the Republican-majority Senate should not act on a Court nominee until after the new president takes office early next year.But in a town hall meeting Monday in Cherokee
column6: Iowa
column7: Grassley indicated he could be persuaded by a large number of senators to take action in a ""lame duck"" session between the Nov. 8 election and the inauguration of the new president in January.""If we have the election
column8: and there was a majority of the Senate changed their mind about doing it in the lame duck
column10: I don't feel that I could stand in the way of that. But I don't think I can promote that idea
column11: he said in a video of his remarks posted online by the American Bridge 21st Century website
column12: which says it is committed to ""holding Republicans accountable.""

column1: Grassley made a similar point at the Sioux City Iowa Rotary Club
column2: Iowa's Globe Gazette reported.Garland
column3: a federal appeals court judge
column4: was nominated by Obama
column5: a Democrat
column6: on March 16 to fill the Supreme Court vacancy created by the Feb. 13 death of conservative Justice Antonin Scalia.

column1: Republicans insist that the next president should fill the vacancy
column2: hoping a Republican will win the White House and choose a conservative rather than the centrist Garland. But such an outcome is not assured
column3: with Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton currently leading Republican candidate Donald Trump in public opinion polls.A spokeswoman for Grassley
column4: Beth Levine
column5: denied he was shifting his position. She said that in Sioux City Grassley reiterated his stance ""that a Supreme Court nominee wouldn't be considered until after the next president is sworn in so the American people have an opportunity to weigh in on this important issue.""

column1: Senate Republican leaders have vowed not to hold confirmation hearings or an up-or-down vote on any Supreme Court nominee put forward by Obama. ""The Leader has been clear: the next president will make this nomination
column2: Don Stewart
column3: spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column4: said in an email Tuesday. (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; Editing by Julia Edwards and Andrew Hay)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-justice-obama-idUSKCN1152JW	Obama shortens prison sentences of 111 convicts: White House	"
WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama shortened the prison sentences of 111 convicts serving time for drug-related offenses in his second round of clemency grants this month
column2: the White House said on Tuesday.Obama has now granted a total of 673 commutations during his presidency
column3: more than the number granted by the 10 previous presidents combined
column4: as he seeks to reform the criminal justice system
column5: it said. For some of the convicts
column6: the commutations mean they will serve only half of their original prison sentences. For instance
column7: Sly Stallone Aikens of South Carolina
column8: serving a sentence of 360 months for using and carrying a gun during a drug trafficking crime
column9: will now serve only 180 months.More than one-third of the 673 convicts had been serving life sentences.

column1: Obama has made reducing the number of people serving long sentences for nonviolent drug offenses a priority. It is one of the rare issues where the president gets support from Republican lawmakers.
He launched the clemency program in 2014
column2: inviting thousands of drug offenders and others to seek early release. It was the most ambitious such program in 40 years
column3: but it has struggled under a flood of thousands of unprocessed cases.The White House counsel
column4: Neil Eggleston
column5: said he expects Obama will continue to grant commutations through the end of his presidency
column6: which ends on Jan. 20. But only legislation passed by Congress can ""achieve the broader reforms needed to ensure our federal sentencing system operates more fairly and effectively
column7: Eggleston said.

column1: (Reporting by Timothy Gardner and Ayesha Rascoe; Editing by Jeffrey Benkoe and Jonathan Oatis)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-eu-usa-ttip-france-idUSKCN1150H2	EU-U.S. trade deal in doubt as France urges end to talks	"
By Sophie Louet and Philip Blenkinsop
| PARIS/BRUSSELS
PARIS/BRUSSELS France cast serious doubt on Tuesday on the prospects of an EU free trade deal with the United States
column2: adding to opposition within Germany and growing scepticism among Americans.Washington and Brussels are officially committed to sealing the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) before U.S. President Barack Obama leaves office in January
column3: but their chances of doing so are being eroded by approaching elections on both sides of the Atlantic and Britain's vote in June to leave the European Union.""Everything is moving. In this situation it's just not going to happen
column4: said Peter van Ham
column5: senior research fellow at Dutch think tank Clingendael and author of a paper on Tuesday called ""TTIP is dead
column6: long live transatlantic trade"".French Trade Minister Matthias Fekl said he would request a halt to TTIP talks at next month's EU trade ministers' meeting in Bratislava after German Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel declared at the weekend that talks were ""de facto dead"".Observers say both are responding to public mistrust of a deal that critics say would lower environmental and food standards and allow foreign multinationals to challenge government policies. Stop TTIP campaigns have been particularly vocal in Germany and Austria
column7: which supporters of TTIP say are among the countries most likely to benefit from increased U.S. trade.In the United States
column9: saying it would fuel growth. But the public mood is turning increasingly negative
column10: with Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump making attacks on international trade deals a cornerstone of his campaign
column11: saying they have cost U.S. jobs. His opponent
column13: has also stepped back from her previous support for free trade when she was U.S. Secretary of State
column14: and has questioned whether trade deals hold down U.S. wages.   FRENCH

column1: German Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier
column2: of Gabriel's Social Democratic Party (SPD)
column3: urged diplomats and business chiefs on Tuesday to counter anti-globalization sentiments that are fuelling opposition to free trade deals.

column1: Ahead of elections in France and Germany next year
column2: politicians are keenly aware that TTIP is not a vote winner. The Bertelsmann Foundation poll showed only 17 percent of Germans saw TTIP as a good thing in April
column3: down from 55 percent two years earlier.""There may be an economic rationale
column4: but everyone is scrapping for votes and you lose votes if you support TTIP
column5: Van Ham said
column6: adding that any credit from potential free trade gains  would be two to three years away.Supporters say TTIP could boost each economy by $100 billion
column7: creating jobs at a time of economic uncertainty as growth and consumption slow in China and emerging markets. EU leaders backed TTIP talks at a summit in June.Speaking to reporters in Washington
column8: White House spokesman Josh Earnest admitted ""significant aspects"" of the deal were unresolved
column9: but said U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman would travel to Europe in an effort to push the talks forward.

column1: I anticipate that when he travels to Europe in mid-September that they'll be engaged in substantive discussions and hopefully will be able to make some additional progress
column2: Earnest said.Three years of negotiations have failed to resolve multiple differences
column3: however
column4: including over public procurement and rules to protect foods from particular regions
column5: such as Parma ham
column6: which the EU wants
column7: and greater access to services and for its agricultural products
column8: as demanded by the United States.""Practically there's no real change. It's been stuck for the better part of two years
column10: director of Brussels-based think tank ECIPE.BREXIT QUESTION

column1: EU trade chief Cecelia Malmstrom told journalists  negotiations had not failed and that many EU countries had said they still backed TTIP.
They included Italy
column2: whose trade and industry minister said it was essential for Italian exporters that the negotiations bore fruit.Germany's Gabriel is the chairman of the SPD who share power with Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservatives. Merkel backs the talks and her spokesman insisted on Monday that they should continue.  Malmstrom added that it made no sense to suspend talks in September because the two sides could still make advances in regulatory cooperation
column3: agreeing standards that are important to industries such as the auto sector
column4: and that could be picked up by Obama's successor even if a deal was not sealed this year.""The more work we have done
column5: the easier it is to resume
column6: she said before a planned video conference with Froman. Froman has said Britain's EU exit will affect TTIP because Britain consumes about a quarter of U.S. exports to the bloc.Trade analysts say that Washington may be preparing for the end of trade talks
column7: which typically conclude with each side holding the other responsible for failure. President Francois Hollande told ambassadors on Tuesday that talks were ""bogged down"" and ""unbalanced"" and it was an illusion to imagine that a deal could be sealed during Obama's term.""Very soon you end in a blame game
column8: said Lee-Makiyama. ""But trade negotiations never really die. They just go into a stock-taking phase."" (Reporting by Sophie Louet and John Irish in Paris
column10: and Madeline Chambers and Andrea Shalal in Berlin; Writing by Andrew Callus
column11: Philip Blenkinsop and Bill Rigby; Editing by Catherine Evans and James Dalgleish)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-insecurity-muncie-specialreport-idUSKCN1151ML	Special Report: Why an emblematic American city has turned to Trump	"
By Timothy Aeppel
| MUNCIE
column2: Indiana

column1: MUNCIE
column2: Indiana One night a month
column3: retired auto workers shuffle into a former elementary school classroom here to discuss their legal fight against the company that cancelled their health care benefits seven years ago.But the conversation often turns quickly to presidential politics.""It can get pretty heated
column4: says Gerald Poor
column5: the group's 77-year-old president
column6: of their political discussions. ""I call it to order if it gets out of hand.""Their anger is understandable. The group is a remnant of a once-powerful United Auto Workers union local
column7: which at its peak in the 1960s represented over 5
column8: 000 workers who made transmissions in Muncie for BorgWarner Inc
column9: the global auto parts maker. An American flag drapes the wall at one end of the room
column10: portraits of former labor bosses line the other
column11: salvaged from a union hall that had its own baseball field.For this group of mostly white
column13: the last two decades have brought much loss. In this election - with the victory of the populist Donald Trump as the Republican Party nominee and the strong run by the populist Bernie Sanders for the Democratic Party crown - many say they feel they're finally being heard again.

column1: Gerald Poor stands in front of the now shuttered BorgWarner factory
column2: where he worked for over 40 years
column3: in Muncie
column4: Indiana
column5: U.S.
column6: August 13
column7: 2016. REUTERS/Chris Bergin

column1: Working-class white men were once a force to be reckoned with in American politics. Many here speak wistfully of how John F. Kennedy stopped at BorgWarner to talk to workers when he campaigned in 1960. For these men
column2: this year's election is a rare taste of the clout they once took for granted.In the primary
column3: Trump received the most votes of any candidate in either party in Delaware County
column4: which encompasses Muncie. Just over 52 percent of Republican voters went for Trump. Democrats picked Sanders over Hillary Clinton by an even wider margin.""Candidates in the past made a lot of promises to the working class in this country and failed to follow through with it
column5: says 66-year-old Bruce Reynolds
column6: who followed his father and grandfather into a career at BorgWarner.Gazing through the rusted chain link fence that encircles the sprawling
column7: abandoned factory
column8: where he notes with precision that he worked for ""32 and a half years
column9: he says he's still skeptical of both side's promises. THE WHITE SLIDE

column1: Neither Trump nor Clinton was his first choice. Reynolds and his wife voted for Sanders in the primary
column2: he says. Among other things
column3: they couldn't support Clinton: She's the wife of former President Bill Clinton
column4: who signed the North American Free Trade Agreement
column5: which many here blame for Muncie's economic decline. They were uneasy with the often fiery rhetoric of Trump
column6: the other side's top candidate.Yet both plan to vote for Trump in November
column7: and Reynolds says they've grown comfortable with the choice.""I know
column9: he says. But they're not.Like many Trump supporters
column10: he glides over the unappealing aspects of the candidate's message to lock onto those that he likes. For Reynolds
column11: it's the hope of bringing back jobs for his children
column12: some of whom still struggle to find decent work.Trump's gloomy world view is often dismissed as hyperbole
column13: such as when he described crime and collapsed economies in America's cities at the Republican National Convention. But for someone in Muncie

column1: Bruce Reynolds (C) with sons Robert (L) and Bruce Jr.
column2: who were once all employed by the now shuttered BorgWarner factory
column3: stand in front of Bruce Reynolds Senior's home in Muncie Indiana
column4: U.S.
column5: August 13
column6: 2016. REUTERS/Chris Bergin

column1: An analysis by Reuters found Delaware County is an extreme example of the declining fortunes of America's white working-class men.In 2000
column2: white men with less than a college degree accounted for about three-quarters of all white men living in the county. By 2014
column3: their proportion had dropped by about 5 percentage points
column4: according to the US Census Bureau. But while this group's share of the population held relatively steady
column5: the earnings of white men with full-time jobs had fallen dramatically.In 2000
column6: 47 percent of white men working full time were in the bottom third of earners
column7: with incomes of $50
column10: 60 percent of them were in the bottom third.Meanwhile
column11: the percentage of white men in full-time jobs making between $50
column13: 000 dropped from 43 percent to 32 percent. And the percentage in the ranks of earners above $100
column14: 000 slipped from 11 percent to 8 percent.In essence
column15: white men in Muncie have slid down from every rung of the economic ladder. They have clustered at the bottom
column16: poorer and more isolated than ever before
column17: even as the overall U.S. economy has grown and globalized.

column1: MUNCIE AS ""MIDDLETOWN""
The same trend is visible in faded industrial pockets from New Jersey and upstate New York to Alabama and Kentucky.According to the data
column2: in about 1
column3: 800 counties across the United States--nearly 60 percent of those where data is available--the share of white men in the lowest group of earners has grown over this period. The trend is particularly pronounced in the Rust Belt states of Michigan
column4: Ohio and Indiana.Jonathan Haidt
column5: a social psychologist at New York University's Stern School of Business
column6: studies how people adopt their political beliefs. ""Trump is the first candidate to speak to--and speak for--working-class white men in a long time
column7: Haidt says. That separates him from the last two Republican nominees. Mitt Romney
column10: ""and John McCain didn't particularly reach out to that constituency"" in 2008.

column1: U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump speaks during a campaign rally at the Allen County War Memorial Coliseum in Fort Wayne
column2: Indiana
column3: U.S.
column4: May 1
column5: 2016. REUTERS/Kamil Krzaczynski

column1: As for Trump's extreme positions and outright falsehoods
column2: Haidt notes
column3: ""If your hero says things that are untrue
column4: you'll cut him slack.""Muncie was once the epitome of America's muscular manufacturing economy. After natural gas was discovered here late in the 19th century
column5: the city attracted dozens of energy-intensive glass manufacturers
column6: most notably Ball Corp
column7: which built sprawling factories that churned out millions of mason jars.The auto industry followed
column8: and Muncie became a hub for transmission making. The term ""Muncie transmission"" is still used by hot rod enthusiasts when talking about gearboxes produced here by General Motors Corp in the 1960s. One particularly powerful version is the ""rock crusher
column9: used in Corvettes and other muscle cars.BorgWarner
column12: has even deeper roots in Muncie than GM. Warner Gear was founded here in 1901 and merged with other businesses to create what became BorgWarner in the late 1920s. Many former workers here still call it Warner Gear.In the 1920s
column13: a husband-and-wife team of sociologists picked the city to study the values in a typical American community. They called it ""Middletown
column14: to conceal the identity of a place they felt was emblematic of the country as a whole. Muncie residents soon figured out it was all about them.The Center for Middletown Studies--at Ball State University--has continued the work
column17: focused on the devastation of deindustrialization. James Connolly
column18: a history professor who runs the center
column19: says that more than anything else
column20: Muncie's working-class white men feel a loss of power. When the big factories were humming
column21: the unions were an unstoppable force--not just for getting good paychecks and lush benefits
column22: but a voice in almost everything else.

column1: UNION POWER
To illustrate this power
column2: he cites a locally famous episode from the 1960s
column3: when waitresses at a big downtown hotel went on strike for higher wages.""A group of police got rough and tried to break up the pickets
column4: says Connolly. A local union leader--who had nothing to do with the waitresses
column5: other than knowing about them through community connections--called the then-mayor
column6: who was visiting Washington
column7: and ""ordered him home"" to intervene. The mayor returned and the police backed off.""The strikers weren't union members--but there was a system of connections that gave them a sense of control
column8: says Connolly. With the decline of the unions
column9: working-class people ""feel like they've been robbed of that voice.""

column1: Boarded up and run down homes sit on a street in Muncie
column2: Indiana
column3: U.S.
column4: August 13
column5: 2016. REUTERS/Chris Bergin

column1: And yet unions
column2: which were unable to prevent the factory closures that ravaged the city
column3: are often viewed just as suspiciously here as most national politicians are. That tension is visible at the old school where the BorgWarner retirees meet.The Muncie Delaware County Senior Center was created to give retirees from the big factories--particularly men--a place to go for companionship and activities. One recent day
column4: the room the BorgWarner retirees use was filled with seniors learning line dancing.""Some people don't like the photos"" of the union leaders
column5: says Jim Shields
column6: a janitor
column7: motioning toward the 10 portraits that adorn the front of the room. They feel the images carry an implicitly political
column9: there was a fuss the last time the building was used as a polling station
column11: when the BorgWarner retiree group isn't meeting
column12: Shields carefully drapes a long bolt of fabric over the pictures to conceal them.Michael Hicks
column13: a Ball State economist who studies manufacturing
column14: says a mix of exasperation with unions and the political elite created the perfect opening for Trump. ""It's always easier to blame a larger force for your problems
column15: whether that's Mexicans or greedy factory owners
column16: he says. ""But these people aren't stupid. They know the jobs aren't coming back."" The bigger concern for many of them
column18: is what will happen to their children.The Reynolds family is a good example. Bruce Reynolds's oldest son
column20: is a Baptist pastor and is supporting Trump
column21: albeit reluctantly. ""I don't think any of them can fix it
column22: Bruce Jr says of the fallout he sees from economic hardship in his congregation
column23: from growing drug addiction to broken families. FROM FACTORY TO WAREHOUSE

column1: Reynolds's second son
column2: Robert
column3: followed his father into BorgWarner after high school. That job didn't last. After just four years
column4: he was laid off in 1994 during a wave of downsizing. He and his father say it was a trauma from which he never fully recovered.""I make $8 an hour less now than I made 21 years ago
column5: says Robert
column6: who enthusiastically backs Trump. After a series of low-paying jobs
column7: including a stint at Wal-Mart and as a manager of a video store
column8: he now works overnight shifts at a warehouse for $18 an hour. He likes the job
column10: although the company recently cut three paid holidays
column11: including the Fourth of July.Robert concedes that he finds the Republican candidate's approach to foreign policy worrisome. ""You wonder if something will upset him and he'll declare war
column12: he says. ""That would be awful."" He also doesn't like how race and immigration has become a theme in the campaign. ""This country was built on bring us your tired
column13: your poor--I think we should honor what our forefathers built
column14: he says.But he also doesn't believe Trump's message is racist. ""I think he's looking at all the illegal activity going on in the U.S. and how it affects the job market
column15: he says. ""He's just not very tactful"" in how he expresses this. Meanwhile
column16: Trump's promise to restore the economy is the draw.To be sure
column17: Muncie has retained some of its smaller factories
column18: and other jobs have come in
column19: including a call center that tracks down delinquent student loans and a Caterpillar Inc locomotive factory that moved into an old plant. But none of these are unionized
column20: and the wages and benefits aren't as high as the old places offered.One frustration for locals is that the statistical measures of the economy don't seem to reflect what they see around them. Muncie's jobless rate is 5.7 percent
column21: less than one percentage point higher than the national rate of 4.9 percent or Indiana's 4.6 percent.But the impact of deindustrialization--including the exodus of over 10
column22: 000 factory jobs since 1970 in a city of only 70

column1: The BorgWarner factory that once employed thousands of people sits shuttered in Muncie
column2: Indiana
column3: U.S.
column4: August 13
column5: 2016. REUTERS/Chris Bergin

column1: Most of the departing companies tore down their factories
column2: leaving lots strewn with weeds and rubble. BorgWarner left a handful of structures--including a 1.2 million-square-foot sprawl of red brick and steel near the edge of town.The city
column3: especially the once-thriving white working-class neighborhoods on the south side
column4: is now dotted with over 2
column5: 000 abandoned houses. Some can't be occupied because they were contaminated by chemicals left behind by meth labs. PHOTOGRAPH FROM A HAPPIER TIME

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the FBI recently opened a probe of the city government
column3: which appears to be focused on possible corruption in its blight clearing program and the sanitation district. The FBI wouldn't comment on the investigation
column4: and Mayor Dennis Tyler said he can't talk about it. There have been no indictments in the case
column5: and it's possible no charges will result.Mayor Tyler
column6: a Democrat
column7: notes the jobless rate stood just under 10 percent four years ago
column9: so there's been improvement. But he understands working-class frustration.""They feel they've intentionally been left behind by trade agreements this country imposed on them over the last 25 years
column10: says Tyler.Trump's appeal here isn't restricted to working-class white men. Another local supporter is Todd Murray
column11: president and CEO of family-owned Mursix Corp
column12: which makes auto parts including tiny switches that go inside door locks and interior lights. His company has grown rapidly in recent years and now employs over 300 people.Murray says he knows some of Trump's trade proposals--such as putting hefty tariffs on goods from Mexico and China--could hit his own business. He exports 60 percent of his output
column14: and operates his own small plant in China. But he insists he's ""not smart enough to know how that would all shake out."" He still strongly favors the Republican standard bearer
column15: who he sees as more pro-business.But the economy alone doesn't explain Trump's appeal. Another family with deep roots at BorgWarner is the Lephart clan. At one point in the 1950s and 1960s
column16: the patriarch and nine of his sons worked there
column17: a fact immortalized in the company magazine by a photo of the group posed on a tall step ladder
column19: except for the brother at the top
column20: who holds the family dog.David Lephart
column21: whose father is one of the nine brothers
column22: avoided the decline entirely through shrewd job-hopping and retraining--but he's still a Trump supporter. He commutes to a UAW job as a pipefitter at a GM plant in Marion
column27: and has put both of his children through college.The 58-year-old says one thing that influenced his transition from Democrat to Republican was talking to his children
column28: whom he describes as part of the ""business world."" His son is now a stockbroker in Indianapolis.""For the first half of my life
column29: I thought Democrat was the only way to be
column30: Lephart says. ""There's this belief that you can't be Republican and union--but I don't believe that any more."" (Data reporting by Maurice Tamman. Edited by Michael Williams)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-rape-bill-idUSKCN1142G9	California lawmakers pass rape bill inspired by Stanford case	"
By Dan Whitcomb
| LOS ANGELES
LOS ANGELES California lawmakers
column2: responding to outrage over the six-month jail term given to a former Stanford University swimmer after his conviction for sexually assaulting an unconscious woman
column3: passed legislation on Monday closing a loophole that allowed the sentence.The bill now goes to Democratic Governor Jerry Brown for his approval. He has not indicated whether he will sign it into law.MORE FROM REUTERS:

column1: The measure was introduced in response to the sentence given to 20-year-old Brock Turner by Santa Clara County Superior Court Judge Aaron Persky in June
column2: which was widely condemned as too lenient.Prosecutors had asked that Turner be given six years in state prison. He is scheduled to be released on Friday from jail in Northern California.""Sexually assaulting an unconscious or intoxicated victim is a terrible crime and our laws need to reflect that
column3: Democratic Assemblyman Bill Dodd
column4: a co-author of the legislation
column5: said in a written statement following its passage.

column1: Turner was convicted of assault with intent to commit rape
column2: penetration of an intoxicated person and penetration of an unconscious person in the January 2015 attack. Under California law
column3: those charges are not considered rape because they did not involve penile penetration.The uproar over the sentence
column4: fueled in part by the victim's harrowing letter in which she detailed the assault in graphic terms
column5: comes amid growing outrage over sexual assault on U.S. college campuses.""This bill is about more than sentencing
column6: it's about supporting victims and changing the culture on our college campuses to help prevent future crimes
column7: Dodd said.

column1: The case has also led to efforts to remove Persky from the bench. Earlier this month
column2: the judge asked for a transfer to civil court.According to the legislators
column3: current California law calls for a mandatory prison term in cases of rape or sexual assault where force is used
column4: but not when the victim is unconscious or severely intoxicated and thus unable to resist.The bill
column5: which faced no serious opposition in the Democratic-controlled legislature
column6: would eliminate a judge's discretion to sentence defendants convicted of such crimes to probation. Under its provisions
column7: Turner would have faced a minimum of three years behind bars.  (Reporting by Dan Whitcomb; Editing by Leslie Adler and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-india-usa-military-idUSKCN114241	U.S.
column2: India sign military logistics agreement	"

column1: By Yeganeh Torbati and Idrees Ali
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The United States and India signed an agreement on Monday governing the use of each other's land
column2: air and naval bases for repair and resupply
column3: a step toward building defense ties as they seek to counter the growing maritime assertiveness of China.The agreement
column4: a relatively mundane one concerning day-to-day military logistics
column5: is nonetheless a milestone in the U.S.-India defense relationship because of the outsized political importance it had taken on in India
column6: where it had touched on domestic sensitivities
column7: experts said. The signing of the agreement will ""make the logistics of joint operations so much easier and so much more efficient
column8: U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter said in a news briefing with Indian Defence Minister Manohar Parrikar.The agreement will allow the Indian and U.S. navies to have an easier time supporting each other in joint operations and exercises and when providing humanitarian assistance
column9: Parrikar said.Washington's desire for deeper security cooperation with India had been complicated without the signing of the logistics agreement as well as two other pacts that would allow for secure communications and the exchange of nautical and other data. The agreements are considered routine between the United States and its other defense partners.But India has had concerns such an agreement would commit it to hosting U.S. troops at its bases
column10: or draw it into a military alliance with the United States and undermine its traditional autonomy. Carter and Parrikar reached an agreement ""in principle"" in April
column11: but had yet to finalize the details.Carter has made closer military ties with India a priority
column12: and established a special unit within the Pentagon last year to promote cooperation with that country. Parrikar's visit to Washington this week marks the sixth interaction between the two top defense officials.

column1: The signing of the logistics agreement indicates the priority the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi places on a closer defense relationship with the United States
column2: said Benjamin Schwartz
column3: until last year the India country director at the Pentagon. ""For years
column4: there has been tremendous misinformation put out into the Indian press about these agreements
column5: said Schwartz
column6: now with the U.S.-India Business Council
column7: which promotes trade ties between the two countries.""What the signing of this shows is that the Modi government is willing to take and suffer the short-term political criticism of signing these things for the longer-term benefit of building the defense relationship with the United States.""Both Carter and Parrikar went to pains on Monday to make clear that the logistics agreement did not allow for basing of U.S. troops in India.

column1: It's not a basing agreement of any kind
column2: Carter said.The debate over the logistics agreement had served as a vehicle for the distrust some of India's political class has towards the United States
column3: said Shane Mason
column4: a research associate at the Stimson Center. The United States had previously imposed sanctions on India related to its 1998 nuclear test
column5: although the sanctions were eased later.""From the U.S. perspective this was kind of a low hanging fruit
column6: Mason said. ""We have logistic support agreements with many
column7: many other countries and in most cases it's a relatively uncontroversial thing.""

column1: The U.S. military has made clear it wants to do more with India
column2: especially in countering China
column3: which U.S. officials say is risking stoking conflict through its claims in the South China Sea
column4: a vital trade waterway.Without naming China
column5: both Carter and Parrikar mentioned the importance of the free flow of trade to both countries.""India and the United States have a shared interest in freedom of navigation and overflight and unimpeded commerce as part of rule-based order in (the) Indo-Pacific
column6: Parrikar said.China hoped cooperation between India and the United States would be ""constructive and positive"" for the region's peace and stability and development
column7: Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying told reporters at a regular briefing on Tuesday.""So
column8: we look favorably on this sort of normal relationship between India and the United States
column9: Hua said. (Additional reporting by Ruthy Munoz and Phil Stewart in Washington
column10: and Michael Martina in Beijing; Editing by Peter Cooney and Alistair Bell)"
